title: CCC: Work|Live|Play@MOA
description: **WLP onboard, educate, incubate accelerator reduces effort&friction while compressing time&space between pro-development phases, non-existent**

f6_assessments.q0:
Unfortunately the proposal doesn't address the challenge in the way it is intended.
Build a mall or in general a physical place where developers can have an infrastructure or a place to learn and connect to toher developers could in theory improve the developer experience, but it's really out of the scope of the challenge.
Unfortunately no tools for developers will be created out of the project, no IDEs, scripts, documentation or anything technical that could attract new developers to the ecosystem.
The impact of this project will also be very geographically localized, but requiring 20% ​​of the funds for this challenge should generate a more global impact.
If the main idea is to create a physical place to educate and connect developers, I would deepen these aspect from a practical point of view, without limiting it to the description of the physical place they will use.
f6_assessments.q1:
The indicated company has many references (even a Wikipedia page), but on the website there is no reference to the person who sent the project. It would be appropriate to make the link explicit and explicitly state whether the proposal is submitted by the indicated company and provide more details about the team who will actually execute the plan.
Even if the proposal is complex, the presented development plan is extremely vague (compared to the scope of the project) and plan is described only on year base.
There is no budget breakdown and no clear explanation for the detailed use of this money.
f6_assessments.q2:
The deliverables are not clear enough, it would be great to have more details about the practical destination of the budget requested and a detailed roadmap for this.
The KPIs indicated are really out of the scope of the challenge brief and extremely vague.
In general I would try to limit the scope of the proposal and try to focus more in-depth on the aspects connected to the developer ecosystem challenge.

f6_assessments.q0:
First of all, this proposal is extremely hard to read! After reading it several time I am still wondering what exactly could be the outcome of this proposal? 
In regard to the challenge setting, it is not clearly defined how this proposal addresses the defined needs of this challenge, and no KPIs are pointing to this challenge. Part of the 5-year plan is to streamline government spending?! How is this part of Developer ecosystem? And furthermore, how does this approach add value to our system compared to initiatives that are already existing and executing? This proposal contains a lot of general information instead of presenting a clear step-by-step plan to show the community what they will get from this proposal.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer is presenting/promising numerous outcomes without explaining and describing how this is to be achieved. Following questions are only some of which I had reading this proposal:
What is your approach in eliminating friction in p2p commerce? Why will this smart contract solution create enormous project confidence? What is your approach in creating a skill sharing culture? Doesn't it already exist (at some areas)? Explain further how you want to construct a highly incentivized tokenomics use case? This sound like an idea, but there is no plan visible. Furthermore, the budget spending is neither broken down nor is it explained. How can we say it is a good use of the treasury?
f6_assessments.q2:
No metrics are related to the challenge setting. No documentation source is provided to enable the community to track the ongoing activities. The roadmap is not clear, as it includes several activities, that somehow rely on each other. No reflection about potential challenges that might occur and how to overcome/avoid them. 
Overall, the idea behind this proposal might be worth to get its chance. However, it might make more sense to start in a smaller scale (there are many related proposals which ask for a lot money) and show the community what they can expect from your contribution.

solution:

experience: MOA, DLRGroup and City of Bloomington via CCC partner with 23 years of complex commercial construction oversight and invite IOG engagement.
